title-group.article-title: Using Artificial Neural Networks to Pick Stocks

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 The Association for Investment Management and Research (AIMR)

abstract.p: Can an artificial neural network (ANN) with automatic learning discriminate between stocks that provide positive returns and those that provide negative returns? The ANN employs a particular pattern-recognition algorithm to learn the relationships between a company's stock return one year forward and the most recent four years of financial data for the company and its industry, as well as data for seven macroeconomic variables. Tests are conducted to determine the ANN's accuracy in predicting future return performance as either positive or negative, or as negative, neutral or positive. The ANN correctly classifies 72% of the positive/negative returns. Its accuracy in predicting the three-state outcomes is below this level but above the level that could be attained by chance alone.
